text:
Assume one has a parameter in the HTTP Request Defaults object with a name 
of "store" and an value of "666."  Later, during recording, one might record a 
request that contains store 666.

It would make for easier script maintenance if the "store" "666" information 
were not recorded in the specific request.  It is unnecessary, because it is 
already in the defaults object.
creator: kcassell@360Commerce.com
alf@i100.no
text:
I think this is almost handled by the Proxy Server today.
From
http://jakarta.apache.org/jmeter/usermanual/component_reference.html#HTTP_Proxy_Server
"
 If the HTTP Proxy Server finds enabled HTTP Request Defaults  directly within
the controller where samples are being stored, or directly within any of its
parent controllers, the recorded samples will have empty fields for the default
values you specified. You may further control this behaviour by placing an HTTP
Request Defaults element directly within the HTTP Proxy Server, whose non-blank
values will override those in the other HTTP Request Defaults. See  Best
Practices with the Proxy Server  for more info.

Similarly, if the HTTP Proxy Server finds User Defined Variables (UDV) directly
within the controller where samples are being stored, or directly within any of
its parent controllers, the recorded samples will have any occurences of the
values of those variables replaced by the corresponding variable. Again, you can
place User Defined Variables directly within the HTTP Proxy Server to override
the values to be replaced. See Best Practices with the Proxy Server for more info. 
"

From the text from the manual, I thought that the functionality in this bug was
present. But when doing some testing, I found that it actually is not working.

One thing that does not seems like it is supported by the HTTP Proxy Server, is
if you define some parameters in the "Send Parameters With the Request:" table
in the "HTTP Request Defaults", and put that "HTTP Request Defaults" inside the
"Target Controller". These default parameters will not be removed from the
Sampler put into the Test plan.
But if you add a "User Defined Variables" element inside the "Target
Controller", then the values are subsitituted by the variable name, if the
values match. So this is a work around that should take care of most situations.

Http parameters are a special case as there may be multiple values.

If there are multiple default parameters, but not all of them match, does it 
make sense to remove just the ones that do match?
creator: sebb@apache.org
shmulikk@gmail.com
text:
Sebb - I would expect this to replace any parameter with the given KEY in the HTTP Request Defaults, no matter what is the VALUE during recording.

I think that the one who put the HTTP Request Defaults in the "Target Controller" of the recorded requests, should take into account that this will override any VALUE for a given KEY.

BTW - this is the same in 2.5

creator: p.mouawad@ubik-ingenierie.com
text: Current behaviour seems fine for 99% of cases, changing this might be risky and ROI very low.
